column4: I haven't had this kind of difficulty installing linux in many years.
Not a good sign for the "grandma" distro
well, it took a while to figure out, but the machine froze up partway through booting, before even getting to the installer
figured out that it needs all of "noapic nolapic pci=noacpi"
So I managed to get the livecd to boot, got into gnome fine, but had no mouse... no big deal, I want to install completely anyway

went to install from the install disc, and first was getting "could not write partition changes to kernel, please reboot asap" etc, couldn't get past that... finally figured it out (not really sure how) and getting through the install, and it complained that tar wasn't available, somehow got past that
and now it's complaining about missing dependencies that won't be installed
I had the same problems on a new Pentium 4 system.
I solved it by resetting the ACPI tables.
A friend of mine actually did it; if you want, I can ask him how he did it.
I was able to boot into the install with disabling the apic/acpi stuff on the kernel params
Go to your BIOS and reset the ECSD data.
Still having troubles with that ACPI computer?
My advice is that you go to the BIOS and hit the "Set to Factory Default" switch.
That's what fixed the ACPI tables on th eother system.
